feed.title: The Register
feed.subtitle: Biting the hand that feeds IT — sci/tech news and views for the world

entry.title: Oracle tunes up Enterprise Manager control freak for 12c database
entry.summary:
Plays nanny to Exalytics in-memory appliance

As Oracle introduces new wares on the hardware and software fronts, it has to plug Enterprise Manager into this new stuff, and so it is with the 12c Release 3 update of the control freak, which was launched concurrently with the availability of the Oracle 12c "cloud-ready" multi-tenant database management system this week.…

entry.title: US states: Google making ad money on illegal YouTube vids
entry.summary:
Blackmarket drugs, how-to-do-crime - it's all just content at the Chocolate Factory

Oklahoma and Nebraska have joined Mississippi in calling on Google to crack down on internet ads for powerful drugs sold without prescription.…

entry.title: Yahoo! slurps! up! auto-shorteur! vidapp! Qwiki!
entry.summary:
Mulph. Feel a bit sick now with all this gobbling

If you thought Yahoo!'s spending spree was slowing down, you were wrong. The exclamatory firm has just snapped up video app Qwiki for a reported $50m.…

entry.title: Speaking in Tech: 'Wanna come upstairs and look at my VRTX?'
entry.summary: Plus: Place a bet on Snowden's final destination

entry.title: EE turns up speed knob EVEN FASTER on 4G spectrum
entry.summary:
You'll need to watch HD in fast forward to make any use of this

Britain's temporary 4G monopolist EE promises to "double" its network speed in twelve cities from tomorrow as the company attempts to achieve superior offerings and differentiate itself from rival operators who are set to swamp the market in the autumn.…

entry.title: O2 and Capita finally ink £1.2bn outsourcing deal
entry.summary:
2,700 staffers shifted - everyone claims victory

O2 has signed the expected deal outsourcing its telephone support to Capita, transferring 2,700 staff in a 10-year deal worth £1.2bn.…

entry.title: Regulator sniffs mobile services bods: 'Something's off. Hand me the probe'
entry.summary:
PhonepayPlus says there's 'evidence' of ransomware-style marketing

UK premium rate regulator PhonepayPlus has launched an investigation into five mobile phone subscription services after it said that evidence had emerged that each had been marketed though ransomware-style browser lock-in tactics.…

entry.title: Growing pile of biz sync 'n' share products try to differentiate
entry.summary:
EMC, ownCloud and Box have been polishing their offerings

There's a burst of activity in the file sync'n'share world as EMC, ownCloud and Box strive to reassure enterprise buyers that their products have the reliability and security they need, while satisfying end-users' needs for simplicity and convenience.…

entry.title: Apple TV 'close' to deal with Time Warner - report
entry.summary:
Hires senior Hulu sales exec to help it with big media negotiations

Cupertino is close to closing a deal with Time Warner that will allow fanbois to watch proper grown-up telly - and Disney films - through their Apple TV boxes.…

entry.title: Government IT contracts to be scrutinised by UK competition watchdog
entry.summary:
How squeezed are small biz outfits who seek public sector deals?

Britain's competition regulator plans to investigate whether too few suppliers command an unhealthy share of the government IT market.…

entry.title: Vulcan? Not on our tiny balls. Pluto moons named Kerberos, Styx
entry.summary:
Astronomers anger Shatner and Trekkies by ignoring public vote

The International Astronomical Union has dissed William Shatner and the public to name Pluto's moons Kerberos and Styx, instead of most-popular moniker Vulcan.…

entry.title: Fitbit Flex wristband: What to wear out when wearing yourself out
entry.summary:
Google Glass, iWatch, activity monitor.... you're halfway to RoboCop

Review  Judging by how quickly Apple is dashing around the world registering the iWatch trademark, by this time next year I could well have a micro Mac strapped to my wrist. And so might many others, if the craze for wearable devices continues on its current trajectory.…

entry.title: Home Office opens up anonymised crime data API
entry.summary:
Please play with our less sensitive bits, UK gov tells mobe devs

Crime-conscious citizens can now view the raw data behind official stats website police.uk after the Home Office made the data freely available to download.…

entry.title: US State Department coughs up $630k for Facebook Likes
entry.summary:
Plus rogue manager left staff quivering in fear of the sack

US State Department apparatchiks spent a whopping $630,000 in a bid to make millions of new Facebook friends on the say-so of a manager who left staff terrified of the sack if they challenged her, according to a recent report.…

entry.title: Broadband rivals 'pleased' over Ofcom's market shake-up plans. Maybe too pleased
entry.summary:
BT overjoyed by 'pricing freedom', TalkTalk says it's good for competition

Rival British telcos BT and TalkTalk have both said they were "pleased" this morning with regulatory proposals submitted by communications watchdog Ofcom on the future of the country's fixed broadband wholesale market.…

entry.title: Show us the money: Big Mike told to up his game if he wants Dell
entry.summary:
Carl: Icahn so afford to back mega-bid to take firm private

Big Mike has been advised to up his offer for Dell after activist investor Carl Icahn finally managed to scrape together the cash to back his refinancing proposal.…

entry.title: Who ate all the flash pie: Samsung, 'course, but hang on... GOOGLE?
entry.summary:
Some surprises in SSDS, all-flash array shipments

Tech analyst Gartner has lifted the lid on its numbers for SSD shipments in 2012 and thanks to Stifel Nicolaus analyst Aaron Rakers, El Reg has some pie chart eye candy for you. First of all, it looks like the startups are catching up with the big vendors in some sectors, which is good news for competition. Also, Google is apparently an SSD player.* Yes, you read that correctly.…

entry.title: Bolivian president's jet grounded so officials can look for Snowden
entry.summary:
Austria: 'It's OK... he's not here'

Bolivian president Evo Morales was obliged to land in Vienna en route home from attending a gas exporters' conference in Moscow over suspicions that NSA-contractor-turned-whistleblower Edward Snowden might be aboard the presidential jet.…

entry.title: Modern-day Frankenstein invents CURE for BEHEADING
entry.summary:
Italian doctor claims to have workable noggin transplant technique

Italian scientists claim they have invented a method for carrying out a head transplant - a discovery that could prove life-changing for patients suffering from hitherto incurable diseases.…

entry.title: Why all the fuss about flash? Pin your ears back and find out
entry.summary:
Stop bluffing and get the facts

Flash storage webcast  Just to be clear, we're talking about flash of the hardware variety, not the software behind those annoying animated ads. This is one of those topics that everyone has heard about, most people have opinions on, but where myths and misunderstandings are rife.…

entry.title: SanDisk buys dose of the SMARTs for $307m
entry.summary:
SSD consolidation speeds up

SSD supply consolidation is starting to speed up, with SanDisk buying SMART Storage Systems for $307m, representing a nice exit for investment fund Silver Lake, and following on from last week's acquisition of sTec by WD for $340m.…

entry.title: El Reg encounters mObi: R2-D2 for retailers
entry.summary:
Is this the 'droid Tesco is looking for?

Say hello to mObi, a metre-tall retail-friendly robot that, if developer Bossa Nova Robotics has its way, will be hovering up and down supermarket aisles the world over, checking stock, guiding disoriented punters to the baked beans, and reducing even further the number of employment opportunities open to surly Gen Y-ers.…

entry.title: Rest your head against a train window, hear VOICES in your SKULL
entry.summary:
'Kill! No wait, give Rupert Murdoch some Monneyyy'

Sky's ad agency has been showing off train windows capable of pushing ads direct into the skulls of tired commuters, as though advertising wasn't all-pervasive enough already.…

entry.title: EMC's ViPR is great ... for other vendors, at least
entry.summary:
Amitabh Srivastava talks to our bod about object storage

Storagebod  Storagebod recently had the chance to chat to Amitabh Srivastava, head of EMC’s Advanced Software division and one of the principal architects of ViPR.…

entry.title: Cloud computers are like bananas, says Deutsche Börse
entry.summary:
It's fungible, so let's funge it

You can agree on the price of bananas even if they don't all look the same, so why not cloud computing services? That's an argument put by the newly-launched Deutsche Börse Cloud Exchange – a trading platform for cycles and storage.…

entry.title: Innovative solution to modern art found: Shoot it into space
entry.summary:
Meteorite-riddled Earthlings to finally return fire at the universe

The European Space Agency says it is seriously considering a plan which involves firing a piece of modern art made from a melted-down meteorite back into space.…

entry.title: Space miners reach funding goal for telescope
entry.summary:
Planetary Resources' Arkyd passes $US1.5 million mark

The world could soon have its first crowd-funded space telescope, with Planetary Resources announcing the success of its Kickstarter campaign to raise $US1.5 million for its Arkyd 100 satellite.…

entry.title: MagicPlay creator crafts Raspberry Pi demo
entry.summary:
'Open source AirPlay' unleashed on the world

Hard on the heels of the release of MagicPlay, the BSD-licensed alternative to Apple's AirPlay, comes the inevitable Raspberry Pi demonstrator.…

entry.title: Carbon capture to biofuel process gets go-ahead
entry.summary:
Algae.Tec signed up for Bayswater facility

An Australian company is planning to install a carbon capture system that will turn a coal-fired power station into a biofuel production facility.…

entry.title: Apple adds Yves Saint Laurent CEO to executive team
entry.summary:
Who better to advise on design, marketing of wearable tech than a fashionista?

Apple has hired now-former Yves Saint Laurent CEO Paul Deneve to work on "special projects", according to a tweet from Bloomberg technology reporter Adam Satariano.…

entry.title: Droid X2 plus ActiveSync equals DATA SLURP
entry.summary:
Oh no, Moto

A Seattle-based security engineer has made the remarkable and disturbing claim that Motorola's Droid X2 using ActiveSync sends sensitive user data back to the company at pretty much every opportunity.…

entry.title: British Bebo founder buys back social network for $849m profit
entry.summary:
Saw AOL coming a mile off

"Buy low, sell high," is the investor's mantra. Michael Birch, the British founder of Bebo, has just amply demonstrated that principle by spending a piddling $1m to buy back the social network he sold to AOL for $850m five years ago.…

entry.title: ACMA lines up 'bill-shock' standard
entry.summary:
Phase-in starts September

Australia's mobile carriers are on notice to do more to avoid international roaming bill shock, with the Australian Communications and Media Authority setting the timetable for implementation of its International Mobile Roaming (IMR) standard.…

entry.title: Citrix open sources XenServer hypervisor to chase clouds
entry.summary:
Forget the complexity: One edition, pay or don't as you please

The XenServer hypervisor is going back to its open source roots, now that Citrix Systems has decided to let go of the code behind its commercial-grade variant of the Xen server virtualization tool.…

entry.title: Windows 8 apps pass 100K, Windows 8 passes Vista
entry.summary:
Faster to 100K than iPad, Android

Microsoft has received two pieces of good news concerning its not-exactly-barn-burning Windows 8: there are now over 100,000 apps in the Windows 8 app store, and the installed base of Windows 8 has passed that of the late and unlamented Windows Vista.…

entry.title: Ubisoft admits major hacking breach, advises password change
entry.summary:
Will latest straw make Assassins seek a new Creed?

French games publisher Ubisoft has confirmed a major breach of its Uplay servers and the theft of user names, email addresses, and encrypted passwords – although it claims financial data is in a separate silo and looks safe so far.…

entry.title: Apple's new data center to be solar powered, 100% green
entry.summary:
PR stunt or canny business move? Ask Barack Obama

Apple has announced that it will partner with Nevada's largest power company to build a solar farm to juice its data center in Reno, Nevada.…

entry.title: Boffins build telescopic contact lenses to battle blindness
entry.summary:
But you'll still need to wear glasses

An international research team has built a set of contact lenses designed to help those of us getting on a bit in years, which can magnify vision up to x2.8 and be worn all day.…

entry.title: PC decline whacks 2013 IT spending projections
entry.summary:
The falling US greenback does its part, as well

We're now halfway through this year, and it's therefore time for Gartner's prognosticators to review what is going on in the global economy, how IT vendors fared in the first half, and to rejig their IT spending projections for 2013.…

entry.title: Apple launches global 'iWatch' trademark blitz
entry.summary:
So far: Turkey, Chile, Colombia, Taiwan, Mexico, Japan, Russia

Reports are popping up all over the intertubes about countries in which Apple has filed for a trademark on the term "iWatch".…

entry.title: Bigger than Twitter: Opera releases rebuilt Chromium-based browser
entry.summary:
Some of the functionality's gone... but it'll come back

Opera, the pioneering web browser, may have only a small single-digit market share but that still counts as a hefty number of people – it has more active users than Twitter. But it doesn’t look like a happy place today.…

entry.title: DataDirect Networks' COO throws in towel
entry.summary:
Keen 'to pursue other interests', apparently

Erwan Menard, chief operating officer of HPC and big data storage supplier DataDirect Networks has resigned, just one month after company-wide layoffs and weeks after the appointment of new company president, Joe Cowan.…

entry.title: Fugitive Shadowcrew suspect hauled into US court... 9 YEARS on
entry.summary:
Bulgarian cybercrime forum member flogged dodgy IDs - DoJ

US prosecutors have finally got their hands on a fugitive cybercrime suspect, nine years after the Bulgarian national was indicted (PDF) over his alleged involvement in the infamous Shadowcrew carding forum.…

entry.title: Sources mutter of 'disarray' among EMC's quadruple object products
entry.summary:
'Come off it, we're set to hit a $1 BILLION bullseye', insist company chiefs

Two EMC insiders whisper to The Register that all is not well at the storage biz. They claim that EMC's object storage strategy is in complete disarray and that senior execs are locking horns over the wreckage. EMC, meanwhile, contends that its current multi-product, multi-teamed object storage strategy is working perfectly well.…

entry.title: Surface Pro for enterprise: We name the dates and the lucky partners
entry.summary:
Also the Pros and cons (and quid Pro quo) of Pro for the pro

The clock is ticking for Microsoft to get its house in order before Surface Pro launches in the UK business distribution channel in the middle of next month, say our people on the inside.…

entry.title: Firefox OS mobilises HTML5, without the added Steve Jobs
entry.summary:
Succeed or fail, you'll still have a working web app

Review  Do you want to build applications for Firefox OS? The first step is to head over to the Mozilla website and sign up for a developer kit.…

entry.title: A short, sharp tool kit to get you to the top in financial IT
entry.summary:
Battling the bullshit artists biz analysts with a Black Swan

Congratulations, you’ve started moving up the food chain. But there is still a long way to go. Having been an occasionally competent head of IT at a midsize City firm after working my way up, I’d like to share with you things I should have known then. These are the lessons I’ve learned at some cost to both my employers and myself as well as things senior IT leaders tell me in the pub. A chunk of this applies to IT management wherever you work.…

entry.title: Nominet resurrects second-level namespace plan: 'Before you say no...'
entry.summary:
Businesses rejected previous consultation

Dot-UK registry Nominet has bounced back with another effort to bring second-level namespaces to life, after the Oxford-based company's previous proposal was largely greeted with indifference by Blighty businesses.…

entry.title: 3-2-1... BOOM: Russian rocket launches, explodes into TOXIC FIREBALL
entry.summary:
Three satellites worth $200m smashed to smithereens

Video  An unmanned Russian rocket carrying three Glonass satellites veered wildly off-course shortly after takeoff and crash-landed in a fiery explosion.…

entry.title: Watch out Tesco Mobile: Vodafone, Sainsbury's want to eat your lunch
entry.summary:
Ringing your granny can now earn you Nectar points, folks

Sainsbury's, the “Premium Economy of supermarkets”, has launched a branded mobile virtual network operator service with Vodafone, offering the usual cross-branding and shelf space – and, of course, Nectar points.…
